fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let \mathcal {C} be a category. The following conditions hold.
If fg is a cover, then so is f.
If \mathcal {C} has pullbacks, then covers are stable under composition.
If \mathcal {C} has finite limits and covers are stable under pullbacks, then for any cover f\colon A\to B, f \times f\colon A \times A\to D \times D is also a cover.
1. Suppose that fg\colon A\to C is a cover and that f = mn, where m is a monomorphism. Then since fg = mng, it follows immediately that m is an isomorphism.
2. Suppose that \mathcal {C} has pullbacks and that f\colon A\to B and g\colon B\to C are covers and that gf = mn, where m is a monomorphism. Then form the following pullback.
Since f is a cover, m' must be an isomorphism. Thus, g can be factored as mg'{m'}^{-1}. Since g is a cover, m must be an isomorphism.

3. Suppose that \mathcal {C} has finite limits and that covers are stable under pullback. Let f\colon A\to B be a cover. Note that f \times f = (f \times \mathsf {id}_{B})(\mathsf {id}_{A} \times f). Thus, by condition 2, it suffices to show that f \times \mathsf {id}_{B} and \mathsf {id}_{A} \times f are covers, but both morphisms are pullbacks against f and covers are stable under pullback by hypothesis.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = {A \times B}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = A, sw = {B \times B}, se = B, west = {f \times \mathsf {id}_{B}}, west/style = {cover}, south = {\pi _{1}}, east = f, east/style = {cover}, } \qquad \DiagramSquare { nw = {A \times A}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = A, sw = {A \times B}, se = B, west = {\mathsf {id}_{A} \times f}, west/style = {cover}, south = {\pi _{2}}, east = f, east/style = {cover}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In a regular category, every cover is a coequalizer of the kernel pair of itself.

Let p,q\colon C\rightrightarrows A be the kernel pair of a cover f\colon A\twoheadrightarrow B and g\colon A\to D be a morphism such that gp = gq. Consider the joint cover-mono factorization of f and g, i.e., the cover-mono factorization of the morphism (f,g)\colon A\to B \times D.

We show that f' and h form a cover-mono factorization of the cover f, so f' is an isomorphism. Suppose that f'a = f'b. We need to show that a = b. To this end, it suffices to show that g'a = g'b since f' and g' are jointly monic. Consider the joint pullback of a and b along h.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = \AA , nw/style = {pullback}, ne = A \times A, sw = E, se = \underline {A} \times \underline {A}, north = {(m,n)}, west = r, west/style = {cover}, south = {(a,b)}, east = h \times h, east/style = {cover}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that h \times h is a cover by , and since covers are stable under pullback in a regular category, r is also a cover. Now we have that
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} fm &= f'hm\\ &= f'ar && \text {by hypothesis $f'a = f'b$}\\ &= f'br\\ &= f'hn\\ &= fn \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Thus, m and n may be expressed in terms of the kernel pair of f.
To show g'a = g'b, it suffices to show g'ar = g'br since r is epic.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} g'ar &= g'hm\\ &= gm\\ &= gps && \text {by hypothesis $gp = gq$}\\ &= gqs\\ &= gn\\ &= g'hn\\ &= g'br \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Finally, g can be factored as follows:
Uniqueness then follows from the fact that f is epic.

An epimorphism f\colon A\twoheadrightarrow B is said to be extremal (also called a cover) if for any monomorphism m\colon C\rightarrowtail B and any morphism g\colon A\to C such that f = mg, then m is an isomorphism.
